8 year old female child following URTI developed maculopapular rash on the jaw spreading onto the trunk which cleared on the 3rd day without desquamation and tender postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy. The diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Option 1
  • Kawasaki disease (KD), also known as Kawasaki syndrome, is an acute febrile illness of unknown cause that primarily affects children younger than 5 years of age. Clinical signs include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, irritation and redness of the whites of the eyes, swollen lymph glands in the neck, and irritation and inflammation of the mouth, lips, and throat.
  • Causes: No one knows what causes Kawasaki disease, but scientists don't believe the disease is contagious from person to person. A number of theories link the disease to bacteria, viruses or other environmental factors, but none has been proved. Certain genes may increase your child's susceptibility to Kawasaki disease.
Option 2

Erythema infectiosum:

  • Caused by Parvovirus B19
  • Children (fifth disease) - Slapped cheek rashes
  • Adults - Polyarthropathy
Option 3

1. Points in favor of Rubella are:

  • Maculopapular rash on the face spreading onto the trunk.
  • Rash is cleared on the 3rd day without desquamation.
  • Tender post-auricular and sub-occipital lymphadenopathy.

2. Rubella is a milder and more subtle disease than measles.

3. Postnatal rubella:

  • Virus excreted in oropharyngeal secretions and infection is acquired by inhalation.
  • Virus multiplies locally in upper respiratory tract & cervical lymph nodes ? viraemia, dissemination throughout the body.
  • Incubation period: 2-3 weeks, fine pink macules first appearing on the face and then spreading to involve trunk and limbs.
  • Enlargement of postauricular, suboccipital, posterior cervical lymph nodes.
  • Recovery within 3-4 days of appearance of rash.
  • Complications: Polyarthritis (adult women, thrombocytopenic purpura, encephalopathy, panencephalitis

4. Congenital rubella:

  • Virus can cross the placental barrier and infect the fetus.
  • Congenital anomalies/death of the fetus.
  • Congenital defects: deafness, cataract, glaucoma, microphthalmia, retinopathy, congenital heart disease (patent ductus arteriosus, pulmonary artery stenosis), microcephaly, mental retardation, thrombocytopenic purpura, hepatosplenomegaly.
Option 4
  • MEASLES (RUBEOLA) VIRUS: Maculopapular dusky red rashes appear after four days of fever (i.e. at 14th day of infection).

Type A

What is the correct preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality?

options.label: A
options.text: RCT > Retrospective cohort > Prospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional

options.label: B
options.text: RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional

options.label: C
options.text: RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Ecological study> Case-control

options.label: D
options.text: RCT > Retrospective cohort > Ecological study > Cross-sectional > Case-control

questions.correct_answer: B. RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ 2. RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional
  • ↳ 2. RCT > Prospective cohort > Retrospective cohort > Case-control > Cross-sectional
  • ↳ Here's an explanation of why this order is commonly used for establishing causality:
  • ↳ Randomized Controlled Trials (RCTs): RCTs are often considered the gold standard for establishing causality because they involve random assignment of participants to treatment and control groups, which helps control for confounding variables. By randomly allocating exposures or interventions, RCTs can demonstrate a cause-and-effect relationship. Prospective Cohort Studies: In prospective cohort studies, individuals are followed over time, and their exposure to risk factors is measured before the development of the outcome. This design allows for the assessment of temporality, which is a key criterion for causality. Retrospective Cohort Studies: Retrospective cohort studies also examine the relationship between exposures and outcomes, but they use historical data. While they are informative, they may be more prone to biases than prospective cohort studies because the exposure information is collected after the outcome has occurred. Case-Control Studies: Case-control studies are retrospective in nature and compare individuals with the disease (cases) to those without the disease (controls) in terms of past exposures. They are useful for studying rare diseases or outcomes but are less robust for establishing causality compared to cohort studies. Cross-Sectional Studies: Cross-sectional studies assess the prevalence of exposure and outcome at a single point in time. While they can provide valuable insights and generate hypotheses, they are generally less suited for establishing causality due to their inability to establish temporality and the potential for reverse causation. Option 2 reflects this general hierarchy of study designs for assessing causality in epidemiology, with RCTs being the most robust method followed by prospective cohort studies, retrospective cohort studies, case-control studies, and cross-sectional studies.

questions.text: A patient who was using CuT for contraception, presented with a 20 weeks pregnancy. The IUCD is placed at the fundus, tail visible at OS and she wants to continue the pregnancy. What is your next step with this patient:
questions.correct_answer: A. Leave IUD in-situ, continue pregnancy
questions.explanation:
IUCD Type Uses Contraindications
Copper IUCD - Highly effective long-term contraception. - Known or suspected pregnancy.
  - Provides contraception for up to 10 years. - Active pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
  - No hormonal side effects. - Current or recent pelvic infection.
  - Emergency contraception within 5 days of unprotected sex. - Abnormal uterine anatomy (e.g., distorted cavity).
  - Suitable for women who cannot use hormonal methods. - Current or recent cervical or uterine cancer.
  - Immediate return to fertility after removal. - Severe liver disease or liver tumors.
Levonorgestrel-releasing IUCD (LNG-IUCD) - Highly effective long-term contraception. - Known or suspected pregnancy.
(Also known as hormonal IUD) - Provides contraception for 3 to 7 years, depending on the type. - Active pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
  - Reduces menstrual bleeding and cramps. - Current or recent pelvic infection.
  - Suitable for women with heavy or painful periods. - Abnormal uterine anatomy (e.g., distorted cavity).
  - May be used as part of medical management of heavy periods. - Current or recent cervical or uterine cancer.
  - Effective emergency contraception within 5 days of unprotected sex. - Known or suspected breast cancer.
  - Immediate return to fertility after removal. - Severe liver disease or liver tumors.
Progestin-only IUCD - Highly effective long-term contraception. - Known or suspected pregnancy.
  - Provides contraception for up to 3 years. - Active pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
  - Suitable for women who cannot use estrogen-containing methods. - Current or recent pelvic infection.
  - May be used while breastfeeding. - Abnormal uterine anatomy (e.g., distorted cavity).
  - Immediate return to fertility after removal. - Current or recent cervical or uterine cancer.
    - Known or suspected breast cancer.
    - Severe liver disease or liver tumors.

questions.text: According to FIGO staging, stage 3 cervical carcinoma involves:
questions.explanation:
Stage Description
I Confined to cervix
IA Microinvasive (diagnosed only by microscopy)
IA1 Stromal invasion not >3 mm deep
IA2 Stromal invasion 3-5 mm deep
IB Invasive carcinoma with measured deepest invasion ≥5 mm (greater than stage IA), lesion limited to the cervix uteri
IB1 Clinically visible lesion >5mm in depth and <2 cm in greatest dimension
IB2 Clinically visible lesion ≥2cm and <4 cm in greatest dimension

IB3

 Invasive carcinoma ≥4cm in greatest dimension
II The carcinoma invades beyond the uterus, but has not extended onto the lower third of the vagina or to the pelvic wall
IIA Involvement limited to the upper 2/3rd of the vagina without parametrial involvement
IIA1 Invasive carcinoma <4 cm in greatest dimension
IIA2

Invasive carcinoma ≥4 cm in greatest dimension
IIB With parametrial involvement but not upto the pelvic wall
III

Extends to pelvic wall, and/or involves lower 1/3rd of vagina and/or causes hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney,involves pelvic and/or paraaortic lymph nodes
IIIA Involves lower 1/3rd vagina but not extension into pelvic side wall
IIB Extension into pelvic side wall and/or hydronephrosis or non-functioning kidney

IIIC

Involvement of pelvic and/or paraaortic lymph nodes, irrespective of tumor size and extent (with r and p notations)

  • IIIC1 -Pelvic lymph node metastasis only
  • IIIC2 -Paraaortic lymph node metastasis

IV

 Carcinoma has extended beyond true pelvis or has involved (biopsy proven) the mucosa of the bladder or rectum
IVA Spread of the growth to adjacent organs (bladder or rectum)
IVB Distant metastases

questions.text: Which of the following is an important factor in the formation of cholesterol gallstones?

options.label: A
options.text: An increase in bile salt concentration

options.label: D
options.text: Age, sex, genetics, obesity, and diet play a role in the supersaturation of bile

questions.correct_answer: D. Age, sex, genetics, obesity, and diet play a role in the supersaturation of bile
questions.explanation:
Factors in gallstone formation
  • Supersaturation of secreted bile (lithogenic bile)- The primary event in the formation of cholesterol stones is the supersaturation of bile with cholesterol.
  • The concentration of bile in the gallbladder: decrease in bile salt concentration
  • Gallbladder dysmotility - Increases stasis in the gallbladder
  • Crystal nucleation - Crystal formation is further accelerated by pronucleating agents, including glycoproteins and immunoglobulins. The nucleation of cholesterol monohydrate crystals from multilamellar vesicles is a crucial step in gallstone formation
Conditions which predispose to gallstone formation
  • Pregnancy
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Thalassemia
  • Terminal ileal resection
  • Gastric or duodenal surgery
  • Rapid weight loss following bariatric surgery
  • Medications (somatostatin analogues and estrogen-containing oral contraceptives)
  • Women and first-degree relatives have an increased prevalence of gallstone disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The lungs are divided into various lobes by division or boundaries known as fissures. A major fissure is also known as an oblique fissure. The Major or oblique fissure divides the left lungs into the upper and lower lobe. The right lung is divided into three lobes by an oblique and horizontal fissure. The fissure helps in the uniform expansion of the lungs .

questions.text: A 45-years-old male was brought to the outpatient department of psychiatry by his brother saying he had become overtalkative again, was speaking grandiose and was predominantly cheerful. His activity levels had increased and he was sleeping just 3-4 hours daily since the last 1 week. He had become easily distractible and kept doing multiple tasks with no completion of any of the same. He had history of 4 such similar episodes in last 6 years and was on tab carbamazepine 600mg/d. He took his medications regularly and hadn’t missed any dose. He had been asymptomatic for the past 2.5years. His brother expressed concern regarding re-emergence of symptoms despite adhering to the prescribed dose of medications. On evaluation of serum carbamazepine level, it was found to be 3 mcg/ml. What could be the possible reason for the same?

options.label: B
options.text: Auto induction of metabolism by carbamazepine.

questions.correct_answer: B. Auto induction of metabolism by carbamazepine.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the physician by his mother becau se of fever and pain in the left ear for the past 3 days. The mother states that he has repeatedly been rubbing his left ear since he woke up this morning. He has a history of atopic dermatitis, and his mother is concerned that the boy's ear pain may result from excessive scratching. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), his pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormality. Otoscopy of the patient is done. Below is the image of the patient's otoscopy . Which of the following statement below is true regarding patient's otoscopy?

options.label: B

options.text: Umbo is not most visible landmark of the tympanic membrane

questions.correct_answer: A. This is an image of the right tympanic membrane

A 12 year - old girl with corticosteroid and cyclophosphamid resistant nephritic syndrome presented with acute renal failure. According to pRIFLE criteria, renal failure is defined as urine output less than?
questions.explanation:
Criteria Estimated creatinine clearance Urine output
Risk decrease by 25% <0.5 mL/kg/hr for 8 hr
Injury decrease by 50% <0.5 mL/kg/hr for 16 hr
Failure decrease by 75% or <35 mL/min/1.73 m2 <0.3 mL/kg/hr for 24 hr or anuric for 12 hr
Loss Persistent failure >4 wk
End - stage Persistent failure >3 months
